CCWD has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the aqueous ammonia process risk management program elements.  The management system activities are further discussed below.

úDetermination of regulatory applicability and requirements
úIdentification of resource requirements, organizational responsibilities, and authorities

These responsibilities dedicate these persons as the resources necessary to achieve the goals and objectives of the risk management program.  Following are the CCWD positions:

úEnvironmental Compliance Officer - Responsible for the risk management program compliance oversight.  General Management authority to obtain the resources necessary to achieve the risk management program goals and objectives

Program Element Implementation

úOrganization responsibilities for the risk management program elements are clearly assigned by position
úPositions responsible for risk management program elements are provided training each time new staff enter the position

Documentation of applicable maintenance and/or operation activities is also important to assess and/or prevent injuries and/or accidental releases.  All records associated with the risk management program are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation.  Following are the locations of the applicable risk management program records:

úSafety Training - Safety training records, as they pertain to HAZWOPER training and related topics, are maintained at the District Center Human Resources Department. 
úTreatment Plant Operations - All Randall-Bold operations records are maintained by Water Treatment Operations at the plant.

Program Element Control

Members of CCWD management and those positions responsible for managing, organizing and maintaining the respective program elements periodically meet to review and assess the program against the goals and objectives of the elements.  Periodic checks and evaluations include annually reviewing operating procedures, per

forming process hazard analyses upon changes to the process, and periodically auditing the risk management program.

Program Element Integration

A change to any program element cannot be made without the input of the multiple CCWD positions responsible for the affected and potentially affected program elements.  As multiple positions are involved in this process, any change in a program element is directly communicated and integrated through participation of all affected and potentially affected program element positions. The risk management program is integrated into day to day operations by:

úConducting periodic CalARP committee program meetings with those responsible for program elements 
úProviding risk management program information to employees at safety committee meetings
úMaking staff aware of risk management program requirements through periodic training and safety committees
úParticipation by staff in incident investigations and emergency drills

This management system satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.6 of the CalARP regulation and ensures that all elements of the risk management program are developed and continually improved. All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained by CCWD for a minimum of five years, unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation.

CHLORINE PROCESS EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Introduction

The Contra Costa Water District's (CCWD) Randall-Bold Water Treatment Plant (Randall-Bold WTP), located in Oakley, California, supplies filtered and disinfected water to the general public for drinking and other uses.  Disinfection involves addition of chlorine and aqueous ammonia to the water to destroy bacteria, viruses and other pathogens that may cause harm to public health.  Other chemicals are handled and safely used onsite to aid filtering and removal of organics and other particulate materials that may affect the taste and odor of the treated water.  These chemicals are not part of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) program, but are handled, stored, and used in a safe manner by Randall-Bold WTP staff.  

The chlorine disinfection process at the Randall-Bold WTP is subject to two regulations - the Federal Risk Management Plan and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP), which is California's version of the RMP.  The initial compliance deadline for both of these regulations was June 21, 1999.  As required by the regulations, an RMP was prepared for the Randall-Bold WTP and submitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency and Contra Costa County Health Services Department (CCCHSD) at that time.  The RMP was then revised and resubmitted to address CCCHSD comments in March 2000. The RMP is now being resubmitted to comply with 5-year resubmission RMP/CalARP requirements.  

Prior to RMP/CalARP requirements, the Randall-Bold WTP implemented programs to comply with several other accidental release prevention regulations that predated RMP/CalARP.  These earlier regulations included California's OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program and California's Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) because of use and storage of chlorine. The California RMPP law was repealed in January 1997 and replaced by the CalARP regulation.

The goal of these regulations and programs (existing and

preexisting) is to prevent and minimize the consequences of accidental releases of chlorine to both on-site staff and the surrounding community.  To meet this goal, CCWD has identified potential hazards, implemented comprehensive accident prevention programs, installed safety and release response equipment (including a scrubber system to treat release events and other process and piping related safety equipment), and prepared for emergencies. The CCWD's approach to meet safety information and associated operating and maintenance procedures and documentation requirements for RMP/CalARP is to build upon the existing programs and regulatory compliance activities associated with the PSM and RMPP Programs. The PSM and RMPP were implemented at Randall-Bold WTP when regulations became effective at the facility.  Most of the compliance requirements, documentation, procedures, and safety programs to meet compliance with these new regulations were taken directly from PSM and RMPP documents or existing operating and maintenance procedures. 

It should be noted that this RMP is specific to the chlorine process at Randall-Bold WTP.  Randall-Bold WTP aqueous ammonia is below the Federal RMP threshold concentration limit of 20 percent by weight.  However, there is no aqueous ammonia threshold concentration limit for the State of California.  As such, all aqueous ammonia use in California exceeds the State's threshold concentration limit and may be subject to RMP requirements depending on storage amount.  Aqueous ammonia use at Randall-Bold WTP is presented in an addendum RMP under agreement with CCCHSD.

Chlorine Safety Policy

Chemicals are widely used in industry, in the home, and in the environment.  They are transported on roads, water, and railways.  We at the Randall-Bold WTP use chlorine to disinfect our water.  Storing large qualities of chlorine can be a hazard.  We take our safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as we take providing a safe, reliab

le supply of drinking water.  This RMP describes what could happen if there were to be an accident, the steps we take every day to ensure a safely operating plant, and what we do in event of an emergency.  Please feel free to contact David Omoto, CCWD Environmental Compliance Officer at (925) 688-8023 if you have any questions regarding this plan.

CCWD Mission

The mission of the Contra Costa Water District is to strategically provide a reliable supply of high quality water at the lowest cost possible, in an environmentally responsible manner (August 1, 1994).
In fulfilling our mission we will:

úResponsibly serve the public. 
úProvide District employees a safe and healthy work environment 
úEnsure fair and equitable rates and charges. 
úWork cooperatively with local, state and federal agencies. 
úPractice ethical behavior. 
úEnsure an open process. 
úEnsure equal opportunity and diversity in personnel matters and contracting

Our goals are to:

úEffectively manage the District's financial resources in conformance with board policies. 
úCreate and maintain a work environment that fosters teamwork and individual excellence to ensure quality customer services. 
úEnsure that all district activities meet or surpass all applicable laws and regulations. 
úOperate/maintain District facilities in a safe and cost effective manner. 
úPlan, design and construct facilities consistent with District needs, and the highest industry standards. 
úMaintain and enhance effective community relations and public information. 
úEnsure high quality water for current and future needs. 
úExercise leadership in water affairs.

CCWD Safety Policies

CCWD's goal is to provide every employee with the benefits of a safe and healthy work environment. The District is committed to maintaining a workplace free from work-related injuries and illnesses, and to complying with applicable laws and regulations governing workplace safety.

To achieve these goals, the District has developed a Health and Saf

ety Program. All employees:

úAre responsible for working together to identify and eliminate conditions and practices that reduce the benefits of a safe and healthy work environment.
úAre responsible for using safe work practices, following directives, policies, and procedures, and assisting in maintaining a safe work environment. 
úMust be familiar with the District's Safety & Health Manual, safety requirements in the Administrative Procedures Manual, and their respective Memorandums of Understanding.  

Management is responsible for ensuring that the District's safety-related policies and procedures are clearly communicated and understood by all employees. Managers and supervisors are expected to enforce policies fairly and uniformly. Managers and supervisors are expected to encourage employees to report unsafe work conditions, practices, or policies without fear of reprisal.

As part of an employee's regular performance review, the employee will be evaluated on his/her compliance with safe work practices. Employees who are unaware of correct health and safety procedures will be trained and/or retrained. Employees who deliberately fail to follow safe work practices and/or procedures, or who violate District rules or directives, will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

CCWD Policy and Program Manuals

CCWD Environmental Compliance Plan - This document contains the District guidelines and policies for compliance with air, water, wastewater and hazardous waste environmental laws and regulations.
CCWD Safety & Health Manual - This document contains specific District safety & health policies and guidelines including the Injury Illness and Prevention Program, and the Chlorine Response Program.

Water Treatment Plant Chlorine Disinfection System

The Randall-Bold WTP supplies treated drinking water to its customers. The Randall-Bold WTP uses chlorine to disinfect water so that it is safe for customers to drink. Chlorine disinfection is a

common process at water treatment plants. The Randall-Bold WTP disinfection system uses liquefied chlorine gas from up to four 1-ton containers. Up to eight more 1-ton containers are kept in the chlorine storage room. A vacuum is used to draw chlorine out of the containers and into the water supply.  

The chlorine storage and use areas are all inside a building that is designed to vent to a scrubber in the event of a chlorine release. The scrubber system can remove up to 2,000 pounds of chlorine gas released inside the building. The areas where chlorine is stored or used are equipped with chlorine sensors that alarm in the event of a chlorine leak. The Randall-Bold WTP is operated and maintained 24-hours a day by highly trained and experienced staff who are experts in the safe handling of chlorine and are prepared to respond to any release situation. Plant access is controlled so that only authorized personnel are allowed to enter the chlorine building. Trained plant staff must accompany visitors.

Potential for Releases with Offsite Consequences

CCWD evaluated two scenarios that might lead to releases. The worst case scenario is specified by the EPA and consists of releasing the entire contents of one of the chlorine containers over a 10-minute period. This scenario is extremely unlikely, resulting only from catastrophic events such as an airplane crash. This scenario assumes that the incident occurs after the containers have been delivered and are in the chlorine storage building because containers are not stored outside. An EPA-developed air dispersion model called RMP*Comp was used to estimate the distance to a point at which the released chlorine gas would no longer present a significant public health impact. The calculated distance for the worst case scenario was 2.2 miles based on indoor chlorine use and storage. This distance may be exaggerated because of the use of the conservative EPA model and the use of conservative weather conditions required in the r

of 1.5 meters per second) in accordance with the guidelines.  Additionally, an aqueous ammonia concentration of 20 percent was used to estimate distance to toxic end point.  This concentration is a set value in RMP*CompTM.  It slightly overestimates the actual concentration to yield conservative results.

Given the aqueous ammonia toxic endpoint (TE) of 0.14 milligrams per liter (CalARP Section 2770.5), the WCS distance to TE is 0.5 miles.  Using census data from LandView¿6, the estimated population within the WCS circle is 1,000.

Alternative Release Scenario

The ARS for Randall-Bold WTP is a 1-inch diameter hole near the bottom of the aqueous ammonia storage tank (7.5 feet from top of tank).  The ARS assumes that it will take outside responders approximately 90 minutes to repair the leak.  The ARS also assumes that the spill will cover the entire surface area of the chemical storage area and spill containment basin during the 90 minutes period.  Using RMP*CompTM, the estimated release rate is 331 pounds per minute (about 41.4 gallons per minute).

Default values found in RMP*CompTM (e.g., stability class D, and wind speed 3 meters per second) were used to calculate the ARS distance to TE.  Additionally, the ARS assumed a 20 percent aqueous ammonia concentration to utilize data readily available in RMP*CompTM.

Given the aqueous ammonia TE of 0.14 milligrams per liter (CalARP Section 2770.5), the ARS distance to TE is 0.2 miles.  Using census data from LandView¿6, the estimated population within the ARS circle is 20.  Because the distance to TE is less than one mile, CCCHSD requires a vulnerability zone for this release scenario of one mile.    The estimated population within the required vulnerability zone is 6,100 using census data from LandviewO6.  There are three child day care facilities and two public parks within the vulnerability zone.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

CalARP requires a subject facility

data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine. Included are chlorine background information, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS), and chlorine reaction chemistry. Chlorine process equipment safety information has also been compiled, including specifications for the chlorine process, maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes. This information is on file at the facility and readily accessible and available to the Randall-Bold WTP staff.

Randall-Bold WTP also has procedures in place to update safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1992, a detailed process hazard analysis (PHA) was conducted by a team of process operating and maintenance experts and process design engineers.  The PHA technique used was the "Hazard and Operability" (HAZOP) study, a rigorous approach acceptable to the EPA. The PHA was lead by a person knowledgeable in the HAZOP study technique. A list of actions to resolve significant hazard review findings was prepared and fully implemented. A revalidation study of the 1992 PHA was conducted in 1999.  Actions items from the 1999 revalidation were developed and implemented.  In June 2004, a revalidation study was again conducted, and an implementation schedule for those findings was developed and is being implemented.

As part of the Cal ARP requirements and the RMP external events evaluation, a seismic walkthrough was also recently completed based on the 1997 UBC, and recommendations were provided to CCWD for evaluation and implementation. 

Process Safety Management Program Summary

Randall-Bold WTP's PSM program includes the programs summarized below that control the use and storage of chlorine and ensure the integ

rity of these systems.

Operating Procedures

CCWD maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that give clear instructions for the chlorine process. CCWD ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  Procedures include startup, shutdown, and normal, alternate, and emergency operation.  Also included are maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to avoid and correct deviations.  CCWD will update procedures whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely. Operating procedures will be modified and in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line and before the process is started up after a change.

Operations and Maintenance Training Program

Each CCWD employee involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process is trained in an overview of the process and detailed, applicable operating and maintenance procedures. CCWD's training program helps our employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from operations involving chlorine on site, and increases the employees' awareness of process hazards. CCWD's training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers: 1) a general overview of the process; 2) the properties and hazards of the substances in the process; and 3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.  Written tests, demonstrations, and field observation are used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the process work can be resumed. 

Training documentation includes: date of most recent review or revision to the training program; type of training required; and the type of competency testing used to ensure staff understand the trainin

g.

Contractors

CCWD has procedures and policies in place that ensure that only contractors with good safety programs are selected to perform work on and around the chlorine process. These policies and procedures also inform contractors of process hazards, access limitations to process areas, and emergency response procedures, and are provided to prepare the contractor to safely complete the work.  CCWD sets minimum contractor safety performance requirements to work at the Randall-Bold WTP, holds contractor safety briefings before allowing contractors near or in the chlorine process area, controls access to the chlorine process area, and evaluates contractor performance.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

CCWD ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process at the plant which is covered by the PSM or RMP rules, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information. CCWD maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. CCWD believes that this program is the primary line of defense against a release. The mechanical integrity program addresses equipment testing and inspection, preventive maintenance schedules, and personnel training, including:

úWritten procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes, and prior operating experience;
úWritten procedures for performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals;
úTraining of maintenance personnel in procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and
úProcedures specifying training requirements for contract maintenance employees, as well as requiring contractors to use plant develo

ped maintenance procedures for process areas.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

CCWD requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the covered processes.  CCWD uses a comprehensive permitting and training program to ensure hot work is performed safely.  

CCWD provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of changes or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows CCWD employees to identify and review safety hazards and gather additional safety, process, or chemical information before any proposed change is implemented that would either compromise system safety or need training before implementation.

Compliance Audits

Compliance audits are conducted at a minimum every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  For internal audits CCWD assembles an audit team of personnel knowledgeable in the RMP rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  In some cases the audit is conducted with CCCHSD as the lead organization.  Regardless of the lead organization, the results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented. The most recent audit was conducted by CCCHSD in October 2001.

Incident Investigation

CCWD investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented.  CCWD trains employees to identify and report any incident that requires investigation.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are docum

ented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff, added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures, and incorporated into existing training programs, if warranted, to prevent future incidents.

Five-Year Accident History

No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at the Randall-Bold WTP that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. Any small, incidental releases are quickly handled or neutralized to prevent off-site impacts and safety or health problems for on-site workers and the community.

Emergency Response Program

CCWD has implemented its Emergency Response Program as well as installed safety systems on its chlorine process such as leak detection equipment and a scrubber to prevent and mitigate chlorine releases. The goal of the emergency response program is to protect its employees and the public in the unlikely event of a release. The two major elements of the emergency response program are an emergency action plan and notification procedures, both of which are described in CCWD's Emergency Response and Evacuation Plan/Employee Training. In the event of a release, the Operator/Supervisor on duty is responsible for immediately calling the on-duty Control Operator who in turn calls the local fire and emergency medical services agency. The Operator/Supervisor on duty uses the plant public address system to announce the plant evacuation. The local fire and emergency medical services agency is responsible for alerting the public regarding the release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

CCWD is in the process of implementing findings from the PHA revalidation study. CCWD will continue to maintain its own safety programs for hazardous materials to protect its employees and the public.

UEOUS AMMONIA PROCESS EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Introduction

The Contra Costa Water District's (CCWD) Randall-Bold Water Treatment Plant (Randall-Bold WTP), located in Oakley, California, supplies filtered and disinfected water to the general public for drinking water and other uses.  The treatment process involves the use of certain chemicals to disinfect the water including chlorine and aqueous ammonia.  Chlorine and aqueous ammonia are used to form chloramines.  Chloramines provide the necessary residual chlorine in the treated water distribution system to ensure the general public receives safe drinking water.

Chlorine quantities at Randall-Bold WTP exceed the State and federal thresholds of the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP).  Chlorine is subject to CalARP Program Level 3 requirements.  

Randall-Bold WTP aqueous ammonia, at 19 percent concentration by weight, only exceeds the State threshold.  The State threshold has no concentration limit.  As such, after consultation with Contra Costa Health Services Department (CCHSD) and based on findings of the worst-case scenario, aqueous ammonia is subject to CalARP Program 2 requirements.

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) addresses aqueous ammonia use at Randall-Bold WTP.  It was originally submitted to CCHSD in June 2003.  It is now being resubmitted in response to CCHSD Notice of Deficiencies Report dated March 21, 2004.  Under agreement with CCHSD this RMP is prepared as an addendum to the existing Randall-Bold WTP Chlorine RMP.

The original Randall-Bold WTP Chlorine RMP was submitted to CCHSD in June 1999.  In accordance with CalARP Regulation, the Randall-Bold WTP Chlorine RMP was revised and resubmitted to CCHSD in June 2004. 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

As a public drinking water utility, CCWD recognizes the importance of protecting the general public.  CCWD operates Randall-Bold WTP in a manner that provides the public with a safe reliable

source of drinking water.  Operation of Randall-Bold WTP not only consists of the proper treatment to ensure compliance with stringent drinking water standards, but the proper handling of hazardous materials to protect the public and our employees from an accidental release and to respond to an emergency.  The proper handling of hazardous materials is accomplished through the use and practice of the CCWD mission statement, policies, plans and programs at Randall-Bold WTP.  

Some of these CCWD policies, plans and programs include specific provisions to comply with the CalARP regulation.  For example, the CCWD Environmental Compliance Plan dedicates a section to CalARP and compliance with the respective requirements.  As another example, the CCWD Safety and Health Manual devotes an entire section on Process Safety Management (PSM).  This PSM section lists requirements (e.g., Employee Participation, Process Hazard Information, Mechanical Integrity, etc.) and CCWD procedures to comply with these requirements accordingly.  The CCWD statement, policies, plans and programs serve individually and/or collectively to prevent and respond to an accidental release.  Below are brief descriptions of the mission statement, policies, plans and programs.

CCWD Mission

The mission of the Contra Costa Water District is to strategically provide a reliable supply of high quality water at the lowest cost possible, in an environmentally responsible manner (August 1, 1994).

In fulfilling our mission we will:

úResponsibly serve the public. 
úProvide District employees a safe and healthy work environment 
úEnsure fair and equitable rates and charges. 
úWork cooperatively with local, state and federal agencies. 
úPractice ethical behavior. 
úEnsure an open process. 
úEnsure equal opportunity and diversity in personnel matters and contracting

Our goals are to:

úEffectively manage the District's financial resources in conformance with board policies. 
úCreate and maintain a work environmen

t that fosters teamwork and individual excellence to ensure quality customer services. 
úEnsure that all district activities meet or surpass all applicable laws and regulations. 
úOperate/maintain District facilities in a safe and cost effective manner. 
úPlan, design and construct facilities consistent with District needs, and the highest industry standards. 
úMaintain and enhance effective community relations and public information. 
úEnsure high quality water for current and future needs. 
úExercise leadership in water affairs.

CCWD Safety Policies

CCWD's goal is to provide every employee with the benefits of a safe and healthy work environment. The District is committed to maintaining a workplace free from work-related injuries and illnesses, and to complying with applicable laws and regulations governing workplace safety.  To achieve these goals, the District has developed a Health and Safety Program. All employees:

úAre responsible for working together to identify and eliminate conditions and practices that reduce the benefits of a safe and healthy work environment.
úAre responsible for using safe work practices, following directives, policies, and procedures, and assisting in maintaining a safe work environment. 
úMust be familiar with the District's Safety & Health Manual, safety requirements in the Administrative Procedures Manual, and their respective Memorandums of Understanding.  

Management is responsible for ensuring that the District's safety-related policies and procedures are clearly communicated and understood by all employees. Managers and supervisors are expected to enforce policies fairly and uniformly. Managers and supervisors are expected to encourage employees to report unsafe work conditions, practices, or policies without fear of reprisal.

As part of an employee's regular performance review, the employee will be evaluated on his/her compliance with safe work practices. Employees who are unaware of correct health and safety procedures w

ill be trained and/or retrained. Employees who deliberately fail to follow safe work practices and/or procedures, or who violate District rules or directives, will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

CCWD Policy and Program Manuals, and Emergency Response Documents

CCWD maintains several manuals and documents that contain policies, procedures, and programs that are designed to prevent accidental releases and to respond to emergencies.  These include the CCWD Environmental Compliance Plan, CCWD Safety & Health Manual, Randall-Bold WTP Hazardous Material Business Plan.  Following are descriptions of these manuals and documents.

úCCWD Environmental Compliance Plan - This document contains the District guidelines and policies for compliance with air, water, wastewater and hazardous waste environmental laws and regulations.

úCCWD Safety & Health Manual - This document contains specific District safety & health policies and guidelines including the Injury Illness and Prevention Program, Emergency Preparedness and Evacuation Procedures, Process Safety Management, and Hazard Communication.

úRandall-Bold WTP Hazardous Material Business Plan - This document contains a listing of all Randall-Bold WTP subject hazardous materials, including aqueous ammonia.  The hazardous material business plan contains a Spill and Release Response Plan that establishes procedures and responsibilities for the response to spills and releases of subject hazardous materials at Randall-Bold WTP.

Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

CalARP requires that the RMP contain a description of the stationary source and regulated substances handled.  The required descriptions are provided below.

Description of Stationary Source

CCWD and the Oakley Water District constructed Randall-Bold WTP jointly in 1992.  The Oakley Water District is now known as Diablo Water District.  Randall-Bold WTP is located at 3760 Neroly Road in Oakley, Californi

a, approximately 3/4-miles southeast of Highway 4.

Randall-Bold WTP supplies filtered and disinfected water drawn from the nearby Contra Costa Canal to the general public for drinking and other uses.  Disinfection involves the addition of chlorine and aqueous ammonia to the water to destroy bacteria, viruses and other pathogens that may cause harm to the public health. Chemicals such as alum, ozone, and polymers are added to aid in the filtering and removal of organics and other particulate matter that may affect the taste and odor of the potable water. Chlorine and aqueous ammonia are the only CalARP regulated substances in use at Randall-Bold WTP.

Description of the Process

Aqueous ammonia, at 19% concentration by weight, is stored in a 6,000 gallons capacity aboveground storage tank (tank).  The tank is located in a concrete walled chemical storage area.  The chemical storage area gradually slopes to a secondary containment basin.  This slope and drainage serve to collect and contain liquid spills from the tank.

For operational purposes, the storage volume never exceeds 5,400 gallons of aqueous ammonia.  The tank is equipped with various devices to relieve vacuum and prevent over pressurization, and control emissions during bulk loading and operation.  These devices include a pressure vacuum relief valve, vapor scrubber, and vapor return line.  In the event of excess pressure, ammonia vapors from the tank vent through the pressure relief valve to the vapor scrubber.  During bulk loading, vapors are returned to the delivery tanker truck by way of a vapor return line.

The primary use and purpose of aqueous ammonia is to form chloramines to maintain chlorine residual.  Chloramines prevent the formation of trihalomethanes in the treated water distribution system.  To form these chloramines, the chemical feed room pumps draw aqueous ammonia from the bulk storage tank.  From the chemical feed room, aqueous ammonia is piped to an injector.  The injector feeds the a

queous ammonia at a point in the water treatment process located before the post ozone contactor.  The aqueous ammonia mixes ultimately with a chlorine solution.  The chlorine solution is added after the post ozone contactor, to convert the free chlorine residual to combined chlorine residual (i.e., chloramines).

Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

CalARP requires an offsite consequence analysis of a worst-case scenario (WCS) and alternative release scenario (ARS).  The purpose of the offsite consequence analysis is to identify and communicate the potential hazards at the stationary source.

The Randall-Bold WTP offsite consequence analysis was conducted in accordance with the EPA document, RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines (guidelines).  An EPA approved dispersion model (RMP*CompTM) was used to evaluate the WCS and ARS.   RMP*CompTM is readily available to the public through EPA.

Following are the results of the offsite consequence analysis.

Worst-Case Scenario

Under the guidelines, a WCS considers a catastrophic release of the entire contents of the single largest container over a ten-minute period.  Given these parameters, the single largest container at Randall-Bold WTP is the aqueous ammonia storage tank.  The tank has a maximum capacity of 6,000 gallons.  By CCWD administrative procedure the tank volume never exceeds 5,400 gallons.

For the Randall-Bold WTP WCS, the model input used passive mitigation.  This mitigation consisted of the containment of a spill in both the chemical storage area (area) and spill containment basin (basin).  For modeling purposes it was assumed that both the area and basin flooded simultaneously.  The depth of the modeled basin was set at the maximum height of the basin. Prevention Program Elements

The prevention program identifies basic elements that are the foundation of sound prevention practices.  Under CalARP Program 2 requirements, there are seven elements in the prevention program.  These elements and CCWD compliance with these respective elements are presented below.

Safety Information

Development, dissemination, and use of safety information are vital to the effective operation of the Randall-Bold WTP.  CCWD personnel use information regarding the chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits on a daily basis and in all strategic decision-making processes.  Accurate and complete information readily available to all personnel is therefore a basic component of the RMP.  This information directly benefits the release prevention program as it provides CCWD personnel with the tools to safely operate process equipment and, as a result, prevent an accidental release.

Safety information may need to be developed and/or revised, and distributed in the event of certain process modifications as described in Section 2745.11(a) of the CalARP regulations.  If the proposed modification is subject to this section, then specific measures will be taken to ensure that the appropriate persons/parties are consulted and/or notified, and measures are in place to ensure safe process start-up.  

For CCWD consultation and notification purposes, proposed modifications affecting the aqueous ammonia process are subject to the procedures found in Section 12, "Management of Change (MOC)", of the CCWD Process Safety Management. The MOC procedu

res comply with Section 2760.6 of the CalARP regulations. Additionally, CCWD will also notify CCHSD as required by Section 2745.11 (a) (1) of the CalARP regulations.

Process startup is subject to the procedures found in Section 9, "Pre-Startup Safety Reviews", of the CCWD Process Safety Management Manual (A copy of the CCWD Process Safety Management Manual is found in Appendix A of the Randall-Bold WTP Chlorine RMP.). These procedures comply with Section 2760.7 of the CalARP regulations.

Randall-Bold WTP personnel compiled safety information, satisfying the regulatory requirements of Section 2755.1 of the CalARP regulations.  This safety information will be maintained for the life of the process.

Hazard Review

CCWD has been able to plan and take appropriate action to improve the safety of Randall-Bold WTP employees, the community, and the environment by systematically examining each process and identifying hazards associated with the operation of the aqueous ammonia process.  CCWD performed a Hazard Review of the aqueous ammonia process in May 2003 to:

úIdentify hazards and credible human errors and/or equipment failures that could lead to an accidental release of aqueous ammonia; 
úEvaluate the likelihood and/or consequence of various release scenarios; determine if existing aqueous ammonia chemical-specific prevention steps and controls are adequate; and,
úWhere existing controls were deemed inadequate, identify additional steps to control the hazard.

The Hazard Review participants consisted of Senior and/or Supervising CCWD personnel from Operations, Maintenance, Safety, General Management, and Process Engineering.  All of these persons were either directly knowledgeable of operations and/or maintenance activities at Randall-Bold WTP, and/or had levels of authority to approve and/or implement recommendations that resulted from the Hazard Review.  The Hazard Review used an aqueous ammonia checklist methodology based on the United States Environmental Protect

ion Agency document entitled, Risk Management Program Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants (October 1998).  External events considered in the Hazard Review include equipment failure and seismic events.  Other external events related to unauthorized and/or intentional activities were also considered in the Security and Vulnerability Assessment (SVA) as required by the Bioterrorism Act of 2002.  Certification of SVA completion was submitted to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency in March 2003. 

In accordance with Section 2755.2 of the CalARP regulations, CCWD consulted with CCHSD on the use of this methodology.  The Hazard Review was completed in May 2003.

CalARP requires that the Hazard Review be updated at least once every five years, or whenever a major process change occurs.  CCWD will update the Hazard Review by May 2008, or sooner if a major process change occurs accordingly.  If a major aqueous ammonia process change occurs, all hazards identified in the hazard review will be resolved before startup of the changed aqueous ammonia process as required by the CalARP regulations.

A formal seismic assessment was conducted in June 2003. It was prepared in accordance with the "Guidance for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Seismic Assessments" document, and included the necessary site visit and review of documents, such as a previously prepared seismic report from 1996.  The seismic assessment presented in Appendix D reviewed various faults including the Concord Fault, with a Maximum Credible Earthquake (MCE) of Richter Magnitude 6.5 and the Coast Ranges-Sierran Block Boundary Zone (CRSB) with an MCE of Richter Magnitude 7.0. The peak ground accelerations identified were 0.20 g for an MCE occurring on the Concord Fault and 0.50 g for an MCE occurring on the CRSB.

At the time of completion in 1992, Randall-Bold WTP construction met all Uniform Building Code Standards, including those applicable to the relevant seismic codes and stan

dards.  The seismic assessment found that there were no major issues or retrofit needs.  There were components, as identified in the 1996 seismic report, that were listed moderate to low in retrofit priority.  These 1996 findings were based on 1995 Uniform Building Code and the more stringent CCWD seismic criteria.  Given the moderate to low priority, retrofit construction was not conducted.  However, none of these components are directly associated with the aqueous ammonia process.

To ensure structural component integrity, visual inspections of Randall-Bold WTP are conducted as part of a Plant Operator's daily walk through inspection.  The inspection includes the reporting and noting of structural components for failure or potential failure.  Any structural component failure or potential failure that might be observed during these inspections would be noted in the plant logbook, and reported to Maintenance for the appropriate follow-up and/or repairs.

Operating Procedures

Standard operating procedures that are clearly written and current and safe work practices can ensure that both experienced and inexperienced employees operate the process and respond to emergencies in a safe, consistent, and prescribed manner. Such procedures benefit the release prevention program by providing operating personnel with clear and concise guidance to prevent and/or respond to an accidental release.  CCWD has developed a written operating procedures program, which satisfies the requirements of Section 2755.3 of the CalARP regulation, to ensure that written procedures and practices were developed, reviewed, implemented, and reflective of current plant practice.

Operating procedures were originally developed in hard copy format as part of the construction contract for the completion of Randall-Bold WTP.  Revisions to the plan have been made over time, the procedures for which are described later in this section.  All operating procedures have been recently been converted to compute

CWD developed a written training program to provide Randall-Bold WTP employees involved with operating the process with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the aqueous ammonia process, and the hazards associated with the process. The training program instructs personnel on safe operating process within operating limits, and how to handle potential emergencies. The training program satisfies the requirements of Section 2755.4 of the CalARP regulation and is described in the CCWD Process Safety Management Manual.

All operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment. The operators receive training specific to the operations of each process when they are assigned to a process. The training criteria are documented in job dimension documents that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system setpoints) and skills to demonstrate competence (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures). Competency is verified in several ways: through written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training. Documentation of training is maintained on file at Randall-Bold.  The files include job dimension documents and certification letters for all employees involved in operating the aqueous ammonia process prior to June 1999.

Refresher training on specific operating procedures (e.g., normal operations, startup, shut down), safe work practices (e.g., limiting contractor access, lockout/tagout), and company-wide practices is conducted during monthly safety meetings, special training classes, and drills. The current schedule was developed with employee consultation and requires that refresher training be conducted every three years at a minimum. Training documentation (e.g., meeting minutes, attendees, instructor qualifications, refresher content, and means used to verify competency) is maintained on file at Randall-Bold.

Training may al

so be required as a result of a revised operating procedure, MOC, or Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR). Supervisors are responsible for ensuring that the Plant Operators receive training for revised operating procedures, and the required training specified in the MOC is conducted prior to implementation of the change. This MOC training satisfies the MOC program requirements of Section 2760.6 of the CalARP regulation. Training records would be attached to the completed MOC or PSSR documentation.  These records and documentation would be maintained on file at Randall-Bold.

The CCWD Safety Officer maintains a matrix of all initial and refresher training, and training conducted as part of MOCs and PSSRs. This matrix, and the accompanying timetable, are used to ensure that each employee remains current with training requirements and is qualified to safely perform their job.  These records would be maintained at the District Center Human Resources Department.

Maintenance

A well-established maintenance program ensures that equipment critical to process safety is fabricated to meet process specifications, installed correctly, and maintained in a safe operating condition. This program allows maintenance employees to preemptively identify and correct equipment deficiencies to avoid an accidental release.  It directly benefits the accidental release program by establishing a program to ensure that all process equipment is properly maintained to prevent equipment failure that may result in an accidental release.  CCWD has developed a maintenance program that satisfies the requirements of Section 2755.5 of the CalARP regulation. CCWD's maintenance program applies to the storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent-systems, controls and pumps and additional equipment deemed to be important to safety by operating and maintenance personnel.  It is based on recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.

CCWD compiles all maintenance information (e.g., preventive

maintenance documentation, quality assurance, the work order system, inspection and tests) for the Randall-Bold WTP on a computerized system (system). This system allows preventive maintenance procedures and inspection and test procedures to be automatically distributed.  A record of all equipment inspection results and identification of any equipment that does not meet the safe operating limits is maintained in the system, which is used to develop and disseminate maintenance reports for delinquent preventive maintenance, work orders, and test and inspections.

The system undergoes periodic review by the Maintenance Supervisor and Personnel to ensure that the procedures and information within the system are current.  Revisions would be made if necessary and employees informed accordingly.  Additionally, maintenance updates would occur for any process modifications as a result of MOC.  The MOC procedure is found in Section 12 of the CCWD Process Safety Management Manual.

An important element of the maintenance program is proper training.  CCWD maintenance employees are trained to recognize and respond to unsafe working conditions under HAZWOPER training.  Additional safety training, such that employee's can recognize and correct unsafe working conditions related to their job tasks, is provided through routine safety tailgate meetings.  The CCWD Injury and Illness Prevention Program also provides a means to educate CCWD employees on safe working conditions, as well as report out and correct those that are unsafe.  For any contractor who performs maintenance work at Randall-Bold WTP, it is that contractor's responsibility to ensure that their employees are properly trained.

Compliance Audit

CCWD believes that ensuring that the prevention program elements are functioning properly (i.e., that they are complete, current, and applied in compliance with company policy, regulations, and good process safety practices) is vital to the continuous improvement of the accidenta

l release prevention program. To this end, CCWD personnel perform internal compliance audits to review and evaluate the written documentation/records and implementation of the prevention program at least every three years. Potential areas for improvement within the prevention program elements are identified during the audit and recommendations are formulated to ensure an effective and improved overall prevention program. Implementation of audit recommendations is verified in subsequent audits.  The CCWD compliance audit procedures described above directly benefits the release prevention program by ensuring that the respective program elements are functioning properly, areas for improvement are identified, and these respective areas for improvement are evaluated for implementation, and implemented if appropriate. 

The compliance audit program developed by CCWD satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2755.6 of the CalARP regulation.  An initial compliance audit was conducted in May 2003, by Mr. Sprio Zapantis, CCWD Safety Officer.  Mr. Zapantis has a Bachelor of Science Degree in Chemical Engineering, and holds valid and current certifications in: Safety; Industrial Hygiene; and Internal Audit.

Incident Investigation

CCWD has developed and implemented an incident investigation procedure to investigate each incident which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a release of aqueous ammonia causing personnel injury or major property damage. This procedure establishes the means to investigate root cause, and develop and implement corrective actions to prevent recurrence of the incident or similar incidents.  Doing so directly benefits the release prevention program through a systematic investigative process designed to prevent recurrence.  The program satisfies the requirements of Section 2755.7 of the CalARP regulation. A description of the Incident Investigation procedure is found in the CCWD Process Safety Management Manual.

Five-Year Accident

History

CalARP requires the compilation of the five-year accident history for all accidental releases from the applicable process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  From the date of this RMP, there have been no accidental releases of aqueous ammonia at Randall-Bold WTP over the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

Randall-Bold WTP is committed to the safe and quick response of aqueous ammonia accidental releases.  In the event of an accidental release, procedures are in place to safely evacuate the facility and notify agencies.  These procedures are described in detail in Section 2 of the CCWD Health & Safety Manual (Reference: Section 2 - Emergency Preparedness and Evacuation Procedures).  A copy of this manual is readily available at Randall-Bold WTP.

Specific spill response procedures are described in the Spill and Release Response Plan (plan).  This plan, which is found in the Randall-Bold WTP Hazardous Material Business Plan (HMBP), establishes response and notification procedures and responsibilities for spills and releases of hazardous materials including aqueous ammonia.  The plan is reviewed and revised if necessary as part of the annual HMBP renewal and submission process to CCHSD.  Outside resources would be requested to respond to an aqueous ammonia accidental release.  These outside resources include licensed hazardous waste contractors, the Oakley Fire Protection District (OFPRD), and CCHSD.  OFPRD and CCHSD are invited annually to participate in emergency response drills.
